item.title: Hugo Picking a template
item.description:
Hugo Themes

Official Themes

You can probably find unofficial themes with a google search, but this is good enough for me. For this site I clicked the tag docs on the side, and looked through a few. I chose this one because it’s simple, has no npm packages, and has an example site that’s ready for use.

If you want something fancier, you pick a theme and look through the setup instructions. Many fancy themes rely on sass or npm, use your package manager to install what is missing. Come to me if you have trouble, and I can walk you through a specific setup.

item.title: Modifying Hugo Content
item.description:
Hugo Content

All your markdown files in the content and content/child directories are what’s used to render the html later. This is why I like an example site. Different themes set up static files and folders differently. They usually have good instructions; however, I think it’s easiest just to grab an example site and edit everything in the content folder, one file at a time and then check it with hugo server.

item.title: About Griz Docs
item.description: griz.sh is my site. I run it on a multinode bare metal kubernetes cluster. If it seems slow, it’s because we are on point to point protocol for internet. At the time of making this about page I have 3 seperate apps running. 2 are made with hugo and deployed with nginx deployments, and content is filled by rsyncing to the pvc. The 3rd is a multiapp django application. I deploy static content with white noise and use gunicorn for the webserver. Instead of using nginx to route traffic I route with istio.

item.title: Hugo is written in Go
item.description:
Hugo uses the excellent Go html/template library for its template engine. It is an extremely lightweight engine that provides a very small amount of logic. In our experience that it is just the right amount of logic to be able to create a good static website. If you have used other template systems from different languages or frameworks you will find a lot of similarities in Go templates.

This document is a brief primer on using Go templates. The Go docs provide more details.
